title: The Sweet (or Not) Smell: Migraines and Perfumes

content: I never really attributed my migraine episodes to certain scents until my nutritionist (the awesome Ryah) suggested it. When she did, it was like nails on the chalkboard (for those of you who remember chalkboards). You see, I’m the type of person who if someone gave me $100, I’d rather spend it on a nice bottle of perfume than a new pair of shoes or anything else.

In fact, when I was in Paris last year, I made sure I visited a famous perfumery. I spent way too much money on sweet scents for me and my loved ones. If that’s not enough to tell you about my love for perfumes, I considered taking a class to learn how to mix my own. Even as a child, I was captivated by the story of the wise men from the East bringing scents to baby Jesus. I wanted to know what frankincense and myrrh smelled like for as long as I could remember.

content_blocks.text: I never really attributed my migraine episodes to certain scents until my nutritionist (the awesome Ryah) suggested it. When she did, it was like nails on the chalkboard (for those of you who remember chalkboards). You see, I’m the type of person who if someone gave me $100, I’d rather spend it on a nice bottle of perfume than a new pair of shoes or anything else.

In fact, when I was in Paris last year, I made sure I visited a famous perfumery. I spent way too much money on sweet scents for me and my loved ones. If that’s not enough to tell you about my love for perfumes, I considered taking a class to learn how to mix my own. Even as a child, I was captivated by the story of the wise men from the East bringing scents to baby Jesus. I wanted to know what frankincense and myrrh smelled like for as long as I could remember.

content: Then -- boom! I was told that strong scents could trigger migraines. Ughhh! Yet another reason migraines are just bad. They steal all the fun!

I also adore the root of most perfumes: flowers. I do my best to keep a fresh bouquet on my kitchen counter weekly. My husband ensures they’re always around as well. If I were a super-rich lady, I’d have fresh blooms all over the house weekly.
Well, I did some digging (pun intended) to see how I could possibly be a perfume and flower lover without triggering continuous migraines. I love glorious scents, but they don’t always love me back.
First, according to the American Migraine Foundation, scents can trigger migraines by activating certain nerve receptors in the nose. Scents can both trigger and worsen a migraine.
Here are some ways I cope:
bullets: I avoid perfumes except for special occasions.

When I do wear perfume, I put in on a few pulse points and I don’t spray and walk into it. I prefer to put it on my skin where I can later wash it off instead of my clothes where the scent may linger.
Most days, I wear a lightly scented shea butter lotion instead of perfume.

First, according to the American Migraine Foundation, scents can trigger migraines by activating certain nerve receptors in the nose. Scents can both trigger and worsen a migraine.

When I do wear perfume, I put in on a few pulse points and I don’t spray and walk into it. I prefer to put it on my skin where I can later wash it off instead of my clothes where the scent may linger.

sections.heading: Cleaning
content: -- including my nose -- needs a break sometimes.
bullets: Yes, I still wear a mask. I wear one when pumping gas, when I’m cleaning the house with chemical products, or doing yard work.
I use natural cleaning products where possible, which tend to have a pleasant but less intense fragrance.
My windows are open throughout the day for fresh air, but especially when I’m cleaning.
I didn’t do this as much before, but these days I take frequent breaks when cleaning. Everything
Just as I do when pumping gas or cleaning, I try to wear a mask when gardening. I’m really trying to color my thumb green. Gardening is therapeutic to me, so I’m going to stick to it.
Flowers smell great, but I just don’t smell them. I might take a short whiff, but I understand that beholding their beauty is enough for me.
Not all scents are bad. I grow lavender, mint, lemon balm, and rosemary -- all of which have shown some benefit for my migraines.

sections.heading: Travel and Social Life
content: The world is full of sights, sounds, and smells. It’s a beautiful world and I can live happily in it -- even with migraines.
Tap into a community of fellow migraineurs on Facebook. Learn, share, connect in our Migraine Support Community .
Photo Credit: JGI/Jamie Grill / Tetra images via Getty Images
bullets: It may go without saying, but I avoid places where I know there will be a lot of smoke. You know the places: casinos, dive bars, and certain lounges. It does mean I miss some events, but I’ve gotten used to it. If I have a choice, I’ll opt for a seat outside.

My nose has been seriously accosted when traveling by plane. Sometimes it’s the passenger next to me (smelling bad or sometimes too good) or it’s just the combination of scents. Once again, I’ll whip out a mask. Or sometimes, I’ll counter the triggering scent with one of my own like a light lavender lotion.
